modules.title: Double-entry Foundations
modules.description: Core mechanics of debits, credits, and the accounting equation.

skills.title: Debits & Credits Basics
skills.description: Understand which side increases assets, liabilities, income, and expenses.

questions.prompt: Which entry increases an asset account?
questions.explanation:
Assets increase on the debit side.
Credits reduce asset balances.
Use the accounting equation to stay consistent.

questions.prompt: Which entry increases a liability account?
questions.explanation:
Liabilities increase on the credit side.
Debits reduce liability balances.
Keep the accounting equation balanced.

questions.prompt: A business pays rent in cash. What is the double entry?
questions.explanation:
Rent is an expense, so debit Rent Expense.
Cash is an asset decreasing, so credit Cash.
The entry reduces assets and equity.

questions.scenarioContext: A sole trader purchases inventory on credit.
questions.prompt: Which entry records the purchase?
questions.explanation:
Inventory is an asset, so debit it.
Trade payables increase on the credit side.
No cash moves when buying on credit.
questions.inPractice: This entry often comes from the purchase invoice.

questions.prompt: Revenue earned on credit should be recorded as:
questions.explanation:
Receivables increase (debit) when revenue is earned on credit.
Revenue increases on the credit side.
Cash is only recorded when received.

questions.scenarioContext: A company repays part of a bank loan.
questions.prompt: Which entry records the repayment?
questions.explanation:
The loan liability decreases, so debit Bank Loan.
Cash decreases, so credit Cash.
Interest would be a separate entry if applicable.
questions.inPractice: Split repayments between principal and interest where needed.

skills.title: Ledger Balancing
skills.description: Track T-accounts and balance them correctly.

questions.prompt: Opening cash is 2,000. A customer pays 500. Closing cash balance?
questions.explanation:
Cash increases by the receipt.
2,000 + 500 = 2,500.
Closing balance is a debit balance.

questions.prompt: A ledger with a higher debit total will have a:
questions.explanation:
The larger side determines the balance.
Debit total greater means a debit balance.
Assets and expenses commonly carry debit balances.

questions.prompt: Opening 4,800. Credit sales 3,200. Cash received 2,500. Closing balance?
questions.explanation:
Receivables increase with credit sales and decrease with cash.
4,800 + 3,200 - 2,500 = 5,500.
Still a debit balance.

questions.scenarioContext: A supplier account shows a credit balance.
questions.prompt: What does this indicate?
questions.explanation:
Suppliers are liabilities, usually credit balances.
A credit balance means amounts payable.
Errors require additional evidence.
questions.examTip: Credit balances are normal for payables.

questions.prompt: Which entry is used to balance a T-account at period end?
questions.explanation:
Balance c/d is inserted to make both sides equal.
Balance b/d brings it down into the next period.
Contra entries offset related balances.

questions.prompt: Opening 10,000. Purchases 6,500. Issues to production 8,100. Closing balance?
questions.explanation:
Inventory increases with purchases and decreases with issues.
10,000 + 6,500 - 8,100 = 8,400.
Closing balance is a debit balance.
questions.inPractice: Use closing balance for the statement of financial position.
questions.examTip: Track movements to avoid double counting.

modules.title: Accruals, Prepayments, Deferrals
modules.description: Match income and expenses to the correct accounting period.

skills.title: Accruals Essentials
skills.description: Recognize expenses incurred but not yet paid.

questions.prompt: An accrual is best described as:

options.text: Expense incurred but not yet paid

questions.explanation:
Accruals recognise costs in the period incurred.
Cash payment may occur later.
This supports the matching principle.

questions.prompt: Which entry records an expense accrual?
questions.explanation:
Expense increases on the debit side.
Accruals are liabilities, increasing on credit.
Cash is unaffected at period end.

questions.prompt: Annual expense is 12,000. Only 9,000 has been paid by year end. Accrual?
questions.explanation:
Expense should be 12,000 for the year.
Paid 9,000, so 3,000 is accrued.
Accruals ensure full period costs.

questions.scenarioContext: A consultancy firm has unbilled staff time at year end.
questions.prompt: Which adjustment is most appropriate?
questions.explanation:
Income earned but not billed is accrued income.
Debit an asset (accrued income), credit revenue.
Cash is not received yet.
questions.inPractice: Use time sheets to support accruals.
questions.examTip: Accrued income is a current asset.

questions.prompt: Monthly salary expense is 2,400. Two months unpaid at year end. Accrual?
questions.explanation:
Accrual equals unpaid months times monthly cost.
2,400 x 2 = 4,800.
Record as liability and expense.

questions.scenarioContext: A supplier invoice for services is received after year end but relates to the current year.
questions.prompt: How should it be treated?

options.text: Record an accrual at year end

questions.explanation:
The cost relates to the current year.
An accrual ensures expenses are matched.
Subsequent invoice clears the accrual.
questions.inPractice: Check post year-end invoices for cut-off.

skills.title: Prepayments & Deferred Income
skills.description: Recognize cash paid/received before the related period.

questions.prompt: A prepayment represents:
questions.explanation:
Prepayments are payments in advance.
They are assets until the benefit is consumed.
Expenses are recognized over time.

questions.prompt: Insurance paid 1,200 for a 12-month policy starting 1 Oct. Year end 31 Dec. Prepayment?
questions.explanation:
Three months are used, nine months prepaid.
1,200 / 12 = 100 per month.
9 months x 100 = 900.

questions.prompt: The adjusting entry for a prepayment is:
questions.explanation:
The prepaid portion is an asset.
Credit the expense to reduce it.
This matches costs to the period.

questions.scenarioContext: A business receives 6,000 for a six-month service contract paid upfront.
questions.prompt: At receipt, which entry is correct?
questions.explanation:
Cash increases, but revenue is not yet earned.
Deferred income is a liability until services are delivered.
Revenue is recognized over time.

questions.scenarioContext: Annual rent paid 24,000 on 1 July. Year end 31 Dec.
questions.prompt: Prepayment at year end?
questions.explanation:
Six months are prepaid (Janâ€“Jun).
24,000 / 12 = 2,000 per month.
6 months x 2,000 = 12,000.
questions.examTip: Count months after year end as prepaid.

questions.scenarioContext: A gym receives annual membership fees upfront.
questions.prompt: When should revenue be recognised?
questions.explanation:
Revenue is recognised as services are provided.
Cash receipt creates deferred income initially.
This matches revenue to the period.

modules.title: Financial Statements Mapping + Core Ratios
modules.description: Place balances correctly and interpret key ratios.

skills.title: Statement Mapping
skills.description: Map accounts to the correct statement line.

questions.prompt: Where is cost of sales reported?
questions.explanation:
Cost of sales is an expense.
It reduces gross profit on the profit or loss statement.
Balance sheet items are assets or liabilities.

questions.prompt: Which item is a current asset?
questions.explanation:
Trade receivables are expected within 12 months.
Borrowings and equity are not current assets.
Current assets include cash, receivables, and inventory.

questions.prompt: Deferred income should be presented as:
questions.explanation:
Deferred income is an obligation to deliver services.
It is a liability until earned.
Typically current unless service extends beyond 12 months.

questions.scenarioContext: A company owns delivery vans used for operations.
questions.prompt: Where do the vans appear?
questions.explanation:
Property, plant and equipment are non-current assets.
They provide benefits over several years.
Depreciation is charged to profit or loss.

questions.prompt: Where is retained earnings presented?
questions.explanation:
Retained earnings are accumulated profits.
They form part of equity.
They are not a liability or revenue line.

questions.scenarioContext: An overdraft is repayable on demand.
questions.prompt: How is it classified?
questions.explanation:
Overdrafts repayable on demand are current liabilities.
They are part of working capital.
Presentation depends on local policy.

skills.title: Core Ratios
skills.description: Calculate and interpret common profitability and liquidity ratios.

questions.prompt: Gross profit is 40,000 on revenue of 100,000. Gross margin (%)?
questions.explanation:
Gross margin = gross profit / revenue.
40,000 / 100,000 = 0.40.
Expressed as 40%.

questions.prompt: Current assets are 90,000 and current liabilities are 60,000. Current ratio?
questions.explanation:
Current ratio = current assets / current liabilities.
90,000 / 60,000 = 1.5.
Ratios above 1 indicate liquidity headroom.

questions.prompt: Which ratio best measures short-term liquidity?
questions.explanation:
Current ratio compares current assets to current liabilities.
It focuses on liquidity over the next 12 months.
Gross margin is profitability, gearing is leverage.

questions.scenarioContext: A retailer has revenue 250,000 and cost of sales 175,000.
questions.prompt: Gross margin (%)?
questions.explanation:
Gross profit is 250,000 - 175,000 = 75,000.
Gross margin = 75,000 / 250,000 = 0.30.
Expressed as 30%.

questions.prompt: A falling receivables days ratio suggests:
questions.explanation:
Receivables days measures collection speed.
Lower days means faster cash conversion.
It can improve liquidity and reduce credit risk.

questions.scenarioContext: Profit after tax is 18,000. Equity is 120,000.
questions.prompt: Return on equity (%)?
questions.explanation:
ROE = profit / equity.
18,000 / 120,000 = 0.15.
Expressed as 15%.
questions.examTip: Match profit measure to equity period.

modules.title: Audit & Evidence Fundamentals
modules.description: High-level understanding of audit risk and evidence.

skills.title: Audit Risk Basics
skills.description: Understand audit risk and its components.

questions.prompt: Audit risk is the risk that the auditor:

options.text: Fails to detect a material misstatement

questions.explanation:
Audit risk is the risk of inappropriate opinion.
It exists even with good audit planning.
It is managed through audit procedures.

questions.prompt: Which is NOT a component of audit risk?
questions.explanation:
Audit risk = inherent risk x control risk x detection risk.
Pricing risk is not part of the model.
Focus on risks that affect misstatement.

questions.prompt: If control risk is assessed as high, the auditor should:
questions.explanation:
High control risk means controls may not prevent errors.
The auditor responds by increasing substantive procedures.
This reduces detection risk.

questions.scenarioContext: A fast-growing startup has complex revenue contracts.
questions.prompt: Which risk is most likely elevated?
questions.explanation:
Complex transactions increase inherent risk.
The nature of the business drives it.
Auditors respond with tailored procedures.

questions.prompt: Detection risk is the risk that:

options.text: Audit procedures fail to detect misstatement

questions.explanation:
Detection risk is linked to audit procedures.
It is reduced by effective testing.
Control risk relates to client controls.

questions.scenarioContext: The audit team plans to rely on IT controls that are poorly documented.
questions.prompt: Which response is most appropriate?
questions.explanation:
Weak documentation raises control risk.
More substantive testing is needed.
This compensates for uncertain controls.
questions.examTip: Higher control risk means more testing.

skills.title: Evidence & Controls
skills.description: Understand audit evidence quality and control types.

questions.prompt: Which evidence is generally most reliable?
questions.explanation:
External evidence is usually more reliable.
Direct confirmations reduce bias.
Inquiry alone is insufficient.

questions.prompt: A preventive control is designed to:
questions.explanation:
Preventive controls reduce the chance of errors.
Detective controls find errors.
Corrective controls fix them once found.

questions.prompt: Which procedure provides evidence of existence for inventory?
questions.explanation:
Observing the stock count supports existence.
Budgets and invoices do not confirm physical stock.
Combine with test counts where possible.

questions.scenarioContext: A company relies heavily on automated invoice approval.
questions.prompt: Which control type is most relevant?
questions.explanation:
Automated approvals are application controls.
Physical controls relate to asset safeguarding.
Segregation of duties is complementary but distinct.

questions.prompt: Which audit evidence is least persuasive?
questions.explanation:
Oral representations are weak evidence.
External confirmations are stronger.
Corroborating documents improve reliability.

questions.scenarioContext: Sales staff both approve credit and record sales.
questions.prompt: Which risk does this increase?
questions.explanation:
Lack of segregation increases control risk.
Controls may fail to prevent misstatement.
Auditors may need more substantive testing.
